source_sentence: 轉輪王品第三(之二)
translation: The Third Chapter of the Wheel-Turning King (of Two)

source_sentence: 「轉輪王有玉女寶者，何等類？
translation: “ wheel-turning king has a treasure of the jadelike queen. What sort is it?

source_sentence: 轉輪王明旦與諸大臣共坐參議，時有自然玉女寶在前現，端正姝好面色無比，
translation: The next morning the wheel-turning king and his ministers sat together to discuss the matter. At that time a woman named Jadelike Jewel of spontaneous birth appeared before him, with an incomparably handsome countenance like that of a heavenly maiden.

source_sentence: 亦不長不短，不肥不瘦，不白不黑。
translation: Nor is it long or short, neither fat nor thin, neither white nor black.

source_sentence: 冬時身則溫，夏時身則凉，身體諸毛孔皆栴檀香，口出蓮華香，轉輪王甚愛重，
translation: The body is warm in winter and cool in summer. All the pores of the body are covered with the fragrance of sandalwood, and the mouth emits the fragrance of lotus blossoms. The wheel-turning king loves it very much.

source_sentence: 意不起婬欲向他人，何況當復身行？
translation: He doesn't give rise to anger in his mind and wants to turn it toward others, so why wouldn't he do so?

source_sentence: 爾時轉輪王甚歡喜踊躍言：『已為我自然玉女寶，今我已作轉輪王。』
translation: It was then that the wheel-turning king rejoiced and jumped, saying, 'You've naturally given me the jadelike woman treasure, and now I've become the wheel-turning king.'

source_sentence: 轉輪王有玉女寶如是。
translation: The wheel-turning king has a jadelike queen treasure like this.

source_sentence: 「轉輪王有主藏聖臣寶，何等類？
translation: “ wheel-turning king has a treasury of noble ministers and treasures, what are they?

source_sentence: 轉輪王明旦坐參議，時見主藏聖臣寶在前，解慧曉事至誠，往至轉輪王所白言：『轉輪王所欲求索者，
translation: The next morning the wheel-turning king was seated in the assembly hall. When he saw that the treasury councilor, the noble minister treasurer, was before him, understanding and attentive to matters with utmost sincerity, he approached the wheel-turning king and said:

source_sentence: 我為天王辦之，王但安隱坐。』
translation: I prepared it for the king of gods, but the king simply sat quietly.'

source_sentence: 轉輪王欲試主藏聖臣寶，使會四部兵，乘船入水，告主藏聖臣：『我欲得金銀珍寶，
translation: The wheel-turning king wished to test the treasures of the treasury councilor treasurer, so he assembled his fourfold army and entered the water in a boat. He said to the treasurer treasurer councilor treasurer, “I wish to obtain gold, silver, and precious jewels.

source_sentence: 當與我。』
translation: You will give it to me.'

source_sentence: 主藏聖臣白轉輪王言：『渡水已，隨王欲，當與之。』
translation: The lord of the treasury, the noble minister, said to the wheel-turning king, 'After crossing the water, I'll give it to him as he wishes.'

source_sentence: 王言：『今當於此用之，疾與我金銀珍寶，渡水已我不用。』
translation: The king said, 'Now, let's use it here; quickly give me gold, silver, and other treasures, and I won't use them after crossing the water.'

source_sentence: 主藏聖臣聞受其教，整衣服船上長跪右手撓水，以器鈔金銀珍寶。
translation: The lord of the treasury, a holy minister, heard and accepted his instruction, adjusted his clothes, knelt down long enough to cross the water with his right hand, and filled the container with gold, silver, and precious treasures.

source_sentence: 譬如蟲著樹，諸金銀珍寶器，著手如是。
translation: It's like when an insect goes to a tree and puts gold, silver, and treasured vessels in his hand.

source_sentence: 爾時，主藏聖臣，持眾珍寶著船上，白轉輪王言：『欲得幾許金銀珍寶？
translation: At the time, the lord of the treasury's noble minister, carrying all the treasures on his boat, said to the wheel-turning king, 'How much gold and silver treasure do you want?'

source_sentence: 今當與王。』
translation: Now, I will give it to the king.'

source_sentence: 轉輪王告主藏聖臣言：『我所有金銀珍寶甚眾多，但欲試卿耳！』
translation: The wheel-turning king told the lord of the treasury, saying, 'There are so many treasures of gold and silver that I want to test you!'

source_sentence: 主藏聖臣聞已，便還持金銀珍寶著水中。
translation: On hearing this, the lord of the treasury and sage ministers returned with gold and silver treasures to put them in the water.

source_sentence: 爾時，轉輪王甚歡喜踊躍言：『已為我自然主藏聖臣寶，我已為轉輪王。』
translation: At the time, the wheel-turning king was overjoyed and jumped up and down, saying, 'I've naturally mastered the treasure of the noble minister who stores it for me, and I've become the wheel-turning king.'

source_sentence: 轉輪王有主藏聖臣寶如是。
translation: The wheel-turning king has treasures like this from the lord of the treasury, the noble minister.

source_sentence: 「轉輪王有兵臣寶，何等類？
translation: “O universal ruler! What sort of treasure is the king’s treasure that is possessed by his ministers?

source_sentence: 轉輪王明旦坐參議，時見有兵臣在前，解慧勇猛曉事，往至轉輪王所，
translation: The next morning the wheel-turning king was seated in the assembly hall. When he saw an army minister before him, understanding and wise as well as courageous and knowledgeable, he went to where the wheel-turning king was.

source_sentence: 白轉輪王言：『所欲為作我為辦，王但自安坐莫憂！』
translation: He said to the wheel-turning king, 'Whatever you want, I'll do it for you; the king simply sit calmly and don't worry!'

source_sentence: 爾時，轉輪王欲試兵臣，使會四部兵，告兵臣寶言：『不曉兵法者教令曉之，
translation: At that time, wishing to test his military commander, the cakravartin assembled the fourfold army and said to the treasured military commander, “Those who do not know how to fight should be taught.

source_sentence: 已曉者教令重知，不曉住者教令知住，不曉騎乘弓馬者教令知。』
translation: Those who have understood it will be instructed to know it again, those who don't understand it will be instructed to know it when they live, and those who don't understand it will be instructed to know it when they ride on a bow or horse.'

source_sentence: 兵臣寶即受教，皆教諸兵。
translation: The military ministers and treasures then accepted the teaching, and they all taught the soldiers.

source_sentence: 轉輪王甚歡喜踊躍言：『已為我自然兵臣寶，我今已為轉輪王。』
translation: The wheel-turning king was overjoyed and jumped up and down, saying, 'You've been my natural treasure of soldiers and ministers, and now I'm the wheel-turning king.'

source_sentence: 轉輪王有兵臣寶如是。」
translation: The wheel-turning king has an army of ministers and treasures like this.

source_sentence: 佛言：「轉輪王有七寶如是。」
translation: The Buddha said, Thus are the seven treasures of the wheel-turning king.

source_sentence: 佛言：「轉輪王有四德。
translation: The Buddha said, Wheel-turning king has four virtues.

source_sentence: 云何為四德？
translation: What are the four virtues?

source_sentence: 一者大富，珍寶田宅奴婢珠玉象馬工巧者眾多，天下人富無有如轉輪王者，
translation: The first is great wealth. There are many treasures, jewels, fields, householders, servants, pearls, jade, elephants, horses, and skillful artisans; no one in the world is as wealthy as a universal ruler.

source_sentence: 是為轉輪王第一德。
translation: This is the first virtue of a wheel-turning king.

source_sentence: 二者轉輪王最端正姝好顏色無比，天下人端正姝好，無有如轉輪王者，
translation: The second is that the wheel-turning king is most handsome and beautiful, with incomparable appearance. All the people in the world are as handsome and beautiful as the wheel-turning king.

source_sentence: 是為轉輪王第二德。
translation: This is the second virtue of a wheel-turning king.

source_sentence: 三者轉輪王常安隱無疾病，身常等等，亦不寒熱，寒熱適其意，諸所飲食食皆安隱，
translation: Third, the universal ruler is always at ease and free of sickness. His body is neither cold nor hot; neither cold or hot suits his wishes. The food he eats and drinks are all peaceful.

source_sentence: 天下人無有如轉輪王無疾病者，是為轉輪王第三德。
translation: Nothing exists in the world like the wheel-turning king who has no illness, which is the third virtue of the wheel-turning king.

source_sentence: 四者轉輪王常安隱長壽，天下人無有常安隱長壽如轉輪王者，是為轉輪王四德。
translation: These are the four virtues of a universal ruler. 4. The universal ruler is always peaceful and long-lived, but there is no one in the world who is as peaceful and long-lived like a universal ruler.

source_sentence: 轉輪王有七寶及四德如是。
translation: The wheel-turning king has seven treasures and four virtues like this.

source_sentence: 「轉輪王以正法行為政現，不轉善現，行十善事。
translation: “The wheel-turning king governs his appearance by following the right teaching, doesn’t follow good appearances, and performs ten good deeds.

source_sentence: 教諸小國王傍臣左右人民，奉行十善事。
translation: He instructed the kings of the small countries, their attendants, and the people to perform the ten good deeds.

source_sentence: 轉輪王哀念諸郡國人民，如父哀子，諸郡國人民，愛敬轉輪王如子愛父。
translation: The wheel-turning king grieves for the people of the prefectures and countries, just as a father grieves for his children, and the people of prefectures love and respect the wheel-turning king like a child who loves his father.

source_sentence: 轉輪王治天下，閻浮利地平正無有高下，無有棘刺，無有毒獸蟲蟻，無有山陵谿谷，
translation: The land of Jambudvfpa is neither high nor low; there are no thorns or thorn roots, poisonous animals, insects, or ants. There are no mountains, mounds, or valleys.

source_sentence: 無有礫石地，但有棄捐金銀明月珠玉琉璃琥珀水精車璩馬瑙珊瑚。
translation: There's no gravel or rocky ground, but there's discarded gold, silver, bright moon, pearls, jade, lapis lazuli, ambrosia, chariots, agate, and coral.

source_sentence: 轉輪王在天下治國時，富樂安隱熾盛，五穀豐熟人民眾多。」
translation: When the wheel-turning king ruled his country under heaven, he was prosperous and peaceful, abundant in five grains, and had a large population.

source_sentence: 佛語諸比丘：「轉輪王治國時，天下有八萬郡國聚落居，鷄鳴展轉相聞。
translation: The Buddha said to the monks, When the wheel-turning king ruled his country, there were 80,000 counties and villages in the world under him, and the cries of the foxes were heard one after another.

source_sentence: 轉輪王治國時，天下常遍有水，草木常青，木常有葉華；
translation: When the cakravartin ruled his kingdom water always flowed everywhere in the world. All the grasses and trees always grew green, and all the trees always had leaves and flowers.

source_sentence: 其地草葉，周匝分布，色如孔雀毛，其香如華香，足蹈上四寸入地，舉足還復如故，
translation: The grass and leaves on the ground are spread all around, with the color of a peacock’s hair. Their fragrance is like that of flowers. The trees touch the ground four inches above their feet as they walk, but when they lift their legs they do so just as before.

source_sentence: 地草又無四寸空缺處。
translation: The ground and grass are also nowhere four inches apart.

source_sentence: 有香樹常生華實，破其實出種種香。
translation: There are fragrant trees that always produce flowers and fruits, and they break down and actually produce various kinds of fragrance.

source_sentence: 有衣被樹，出華實及種種衣被。
translation: There are robes covered with trees that produce flowers, fruits, and various kinds of robes.

source_sentence: 有珠寶瓔珞樹出華實，破中有無央數種種珠寶瓔珞。
translation: There's a tree of jeweled jewelry that produces flowers and fruits, and there's an incalculable number of various kinds of jeweled jewelry in the breach.

source_sentence: 有不息華樹出華實，破中有種種不息。
translation: There's an unceasing flower tree that produces flowers and fruits, and there are various kinds of unceasing in the broken fruit.

source_sentence: 有果樹，常生華實，破中有種種果。
translation: There's a fruit tree that always produces flowers and fruits, and there are various fruits in the broken fruit.

source_sentence: 有器樹生華實，破中有種種器。
translation: There's a container tree that produces flowers and fruits, and there are various containers in the refutation.

source_sentence: 有妓樂樹生華實，破中有種種音樂。
translation: There's a tree of music that produces flowers and fruits, and there are various kinds of music in the breach.

source_sentence: 轉輪王治國，是時天下閻浮利不耕種，米穀稻粮皆自然生，清潔無穬，
translation: When the wheel-turning king ruled his country, Jambudvfpa under heaven did not cultivate soil; rice, grain, rice, and cereals all arose naturally, being pure and without abscesses.

source_sentence: 出其有種種甘。
translation: It produces various kinds of sweetness.

source_sentence: 轉輪王臨壽終時，身不甚痛。
translation: When the wheel-turning king's life came to an end, his body didn't experience much pain.

source_sentence: 譬如習樂人大食，腹不甚痛。
translation: It's like eating a large amount of food that's cultivated for pleasure and doesn't cause great pain in the abdomen.

source_sentence: 轉輪王臨壽終時，身體不痛如是。
translation: When the wheel-turning king's life came to an end, his body didn't hurt like this.

source_sentence: 轉輪王命過已後，金輪、白象寶便滅去，紺色馬、明月珠寶亦沒去，玉女寶、主藏聖臣寶、導道聖臣寶，
translation: After the wheel-turning king had passed away, the golden wheel and the white elephant treasures disappeared; the dark blue horse and the moon jewel in the morning also disappeared. The jadelike queen treasure, the treasury treasure, the holy attendant treasure of the ruler, and the holy attendant treasure of the Guide of the Way all disappeared.

source_sentence: 便沐浴轉輪王身，以綿纏身，復以五百張[疊*毛]纏身，著鐵棺中，
translation: He then bathed the body of the wheel-turning king, covered it with cotton cloth, wrapped it in another five hundred patches of cotton cloth, and buried it in an iron coffin.

source_sentence: 以酥灌其上，滿已蓋覆之，以釘釘之。
translation: He pours butter over it, covers it with a lid that's full, and nailes it with a nail.

source_sentence: 出轉輪王棺，眾人共作妓樂歌舞。
translation: The coffin of the universal ruler came out, and all the people performed music, singing and dancing together.

source_sentence: 出著城外，積一切香薪，持轉輪王棺，著上便放火燒。
translation: Outside the city, he stored all kinds of fragrant wood and carried a universal coffin. When he ascended to it, he set fire to burn it.

source_sentence: 燒已玉女寶、主藏聖臣寶、導道聖臣寶，共收骨以置於四徼道中起塔，
translation: Having burned the treasures of the jadelike queen, the treasures of the treasury councilor and the treasures of the holy ministers who led the way, they collected the bones together and placed them in a stupa built on the four sides of the road.

source_sentence: 高四十里，廣長四十里，周匝起墻廣長二百里，以七寶金銀水精琉璃赤真珠車璩馬瑙，
translation: It was forty li high and forty li long, two hundred li in all directions surrounded by walls built of the seven kinds of treasure: gold, silver, crystal, lapis lazuli, ruby, pearls, chariots, agate, and horse ashes.

source_sentence: 七重欄楯、七重交露、七重行樹，周匝圍遶，甚姝好。
translation: It is surrounded by sevenfold railings, sevenfold interlocks, and sevenfold lines of trees that are very beautiful.

source_sentence: 其從四方來，禮轉輪王，行法起塔，皆得無數福。
translation: Those who come from the four directions venerate wheel-turning kings, practice the Dharma, and build stūpas will attain countless merits.

source_sentence: 爾時玉女寶、主藏聖臣寶、導道聖臣寶，為轉輪王起塔已，便布施飢者與飯，
translation: It was then that the treasure of the jadelike queen, the treasure of the treasury lord, the treasure of the noble ministers, and the treasure of the noble ministers guiding the path were built a stūpa for the wheel-turning king, and he gave it to the hungry man and gave him food.

source_sentence: 渴者與漿，欲得衣者與衣，欲得香熏華者與香熏華，欲得財物牛羊者與之。
translation: Those who are thirsty give wine, those who want to get robes give robes, those who want to obtain fragrant flowers give fragrant flowers, and those who want to obtain property or cattle and sheep give it.

source_sentence: 其後玉女寶、主藏聖臣寶、導道聖臣寶乃命過。」
translation: After that, the treasure of the jadelike queen, the treasure of the lord of the treasury, the treasure of the noble ministers of the path, and the treasure of the noble ministers of the path were ordered to pass away.

source_sentence: 大樓炭經泥犁品第四(之一)
translation: Chapter Four (one) of the Niraya Chapter of the Sutra on the Cultivation of Charcoal Trees

source_sentence: 佛告比丘：「有大鐵圍山，更復有第二大鐵圍山，中間窈窈冥冥，其日月大尊神光明不能及照。
translation: The Buddha told the monks, There's a large iron ring mountain and another large iron ring mountain in between, which is so dark and mysterious that the sun and moon of the great venerable god cannot match its illumination.

source_sentence: 其中有八大泥犁，一泥犁者，有十六部。
translation: Among them there are eight great mud plows, and the one mud plow has sixteen parts.

source_sentence: 第一大泥犁名想、第二大泥犁名黑耳、第三大泥犁名僧乾、第四大泥犁名樓獵、第五大泥犁名噭嚾、第六大泥犁名燒炙、第七大泥犁名釜煮、第八大泥犁名阿鼻摩訶。」
translation: The first great nirvāṇa is called conception, the second great nirvāṇa is called black ears, the third great nirvāṇa is called dryness, the fourth great nirvāṇa is called hunting, the fifth great nirvāṇa is called torment, the sixth great nirvāṇa is called burning, the seventh great nirvāṇa is called cooking

source_sentence: 佛言：「何以名為想？
translation: The Buddha said, What's called conception?

source_sentence: 其大想泥犁，若有人墮中，其八指生爪如利刀，以相把刺，其肉應手墮去，
translation: If someone were to fall into that great imagined mud plow, their eight fingers would give rise to nails like sharp swords, and if they touched each other with a thorn, the flesh would fall off in their hands.

source_sentence: 想念欲相殺，以是麤事，名為想泥犁。
translation: Thinking of each other and wanting to kill each other, this is called conceptualizing the mud plow because it's a debilitating thing.

source_sentence: 更復有餘種種因緣，復次，其大想泥犁，若有人墮中者，手中自然刀劍，
translation: Furthermore, there are various other causes and conditions. Furthermore, the great ideation is that if someone falls into a mud plow, they'll naturally have a sword in their hand.

source_sentence: 以相斫刺，想欲殺他人，以是麤想事故，名為想。
translation: To think of sexual misconduct as wanting to kill others, and to think of sexual misconduct as an incident that's called conception.

source_sentence: 復有餘因緣，其有人墮中者，手自然小刀，以刺剝他人，想念欲殺之，
translation: Again, suppose there are other reasons why a man falls into the middle. He naturally has a small knife in his hand to pierce others and thinks he wants to kill them.

source_sentence: 以是麤想事故，名為想。
translation: It's called perception because it's the cause of debilitating perception.

source_sentence: 復有餘因緣，其有人墮大想泥犁中者，以手搔從足剝餘者至頂，想念欲殺他人，
translation: Again, there are other reasons why some people fall into the great conceptual mud plow. They scrape the remaining parts up to the top of their heads with their hands and think that they want to kill others.

source_sentence: 涼風起吹之，身瘡平復，展轉相語，當復長生，中復有相語言：『我曹今適生。』
translation: When a cool breeze arises and blows it, the sores on their bodies are restored, and they talk to each other in turn, and they'll be born again for a long time.

source_sentence: 以是故，名為想泥犁。
translation: Because of this, it's called the imagined mud plow.

source_sentence: 復有餘因緣，用是故泥犁人壽長久，乃從想泥犁中出，便走求解脫。
translation: Again, there are other causes and conditions that make it possible for people to have a long life span in the mud plow because of which they emerge from the mud plow of ideation and then run away to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「復有泥犁，名為黑界，縱廣二萬里，悉入中裏，火從身出，繞身三匝還入身，
translation: Again, there is a mud plow called the “dark realm.” Twenty thousand li in all directions and twenty thousand li in width, it enters inside and out. The fire emerges from its body, circumambulates it three times, and returns within.

source_sentence: 毒痛不可忍，過惡未解故不死。
translation: The poisonous pain is unbearable, and they won't die because their faults haven't been resolved.

source_sentence: 復次，黑界泥犁東壁火繞三匝燒人，火焰至西壁，西壁火焰至東壁，南壁火焰至北壁，
translation: Again, the fire circled the eastern wall of the niraya of the black realm three times and burned people. The flame of the fire reached the western wall, the flame of the western wall reached the eastern wall, and the flame of the southern wall reached the northern wall.

source_sentence: 北壁火焰至南壁，上火焰下至地，下焰上至上，人在中燒炙，毒痛不可忍，
translation: The flame of the fire from the northern wall reaches the southern wall, and the flame from the upper one reaches the ground; the flame from the lower one reaches up to the upper one. All the people in this hell are burned and tormented with unbearable pain and suffering.

source_sentence: 過惡未解故不死，在其中甚久久，乃從黑界泥犁出，便走求解脫。
translation: Because their faults and evils haven't been untied, they won't die. After being there for a long time, they emerge from the mud plow of the black realm and run away to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名沸屎，縱廣二萬里，悉入沸屎中，自然至頸，熱沸踊躍，人以把蹶，
translation: “There’s a mud plow called Boiling Excrement, twenty thousand li in length and width, which naturally reaches its neck when it enters boiling excrement.

source_sentence: 欲出不能得，身體手足耳鼻面目皆爛熟，毒痛不可忍，過惡未盡故不死；
translation: Their bodies, hands, feet, ears, nose, face, and eyes all rotten away. The pain of the poison cannot be tolerated; they do not die until their faults have been eliminated.

source_sentence: 有蟲名鐵口，啄人髑髏，啄人肉穿之，破骨噉人髓。
translation: There's a worm named iron mouth that pecks at people's skulls, pecks into their flesh, penetrates it, breaks through their bones, and digs up human marrow.

source_sentence: 泥犁中人，手捲屎食之，脣舌皆燋，咽喉腹中腸胃皆爛，便下過去，毒痛不可忍，
translation: A man in a mud plow eats the excrement with his hands wrapped around it. His lips and tongue all blistering, his throat, abdomen, stomach, intestines, and stomach all rotting away, and he goes down and passes on, unbearably pained by the poison.

source_sentence: 過惡未盡故不死，在其中甚久，以後乃從沸屎泥犁中出，便走欲求解脫。
translation: Because their faults and evils haven't ended, they won't die; they stay there for a long time. After that, they emerge from the boiling mud plow and run away to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名五百釘，縱廣二萬里悉入中，泥犁旁各取人手足，臥撲著釘地，
translation: “There’s a mud plow called Five Hundred Nails, twenty thousand li in length and width, all entering into it. At the side of each mud plow people take their hands and feet and prostrate them on the ground with their legs touching the nails.

source_sentence: 以燒鐵釘釘其右掌，以鐵釘釘左掌，以鐵釘釘其右足，復以鐵釘釘其左足、復以鐵釘釘其心、復以鐵釘遍釘其身下徹地，
translation: He fastened his right palm with a burning iron nailing, his left palm with an iron nailing, his right foot with an iron nailing, his left foot with an iron nailing, his heart with an iron nailing, and his whole body with an iron nailing that penetrated the ground beneath him.

source_sentence: 悉以五百釘釘其身，續動欲起，毒痛不可忍。
translation: They all nailed their bodies with five hundred nails, continuing to move and wanting to give rise to pain and suffering unbearable.

source_sentence: 泥犁旁問言：『欲求何等？』
translation: Aside the mud plow, he asked, 'What do you want?'

source_sentence: 報言：『我但苦飢渴！』
translation: They replied, 'I'm only suffering from hunger and thirst!'

source_sentence: 泥犁旁取鉗拗開口，燒熱鐵著其咽中，脣舌咽皆燋，腹中腸胃皆燋爛，
translation: At the side of the mud plow, he takes a forceps and opens his mouth. Burning hot iron is placed in his throat. His lips, tongue, and throat are all scorched, and everything in his abdomen, intestines, and stomach are burned away.

source_sentence: 與腸胃下過去，毒痛不可忍，過惡未盡故不死，用是故人在泥犁中甚長久，
translation: The poison and pain they experience cannot be tolerated. They do not die until the exhaustion of their past evil deeds. For this reason, for a very long time people live in mud plows.

source_sentence: 以後乃從五百釘泥犁得出，便走求欲解脫。
translation: After that, he emerged from the five hundred naked mud plows and ran away in search of liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名車怗，縱廣二萬里，悉入其中，泥犁旁便問言：『欲求何等？』
translation: There's a mud plow named chariot, 20,000 miles long and wide, that all enters it, and beside the mud plow he asks, 'What do you want?'

source_sentence: 報言：『但苦飢渴。』
translation: They replied, 'It's only painful hunger and thirst.'

source_sentence: 泥犁旁便各各取其身撲著地，取鉗拗開其口，取消銅灌人口，脣舌皆燋，
translation: Beside the mud plow, they each took their bodies and pushed them to the ground. Using forceps and blows, they opened their mouths, expelled the copper clay that had been poured into the earth, and their lips and tongues stuck together.

source_sentence: 腹中五藏腸胃，皆燋爛燒炙，毒痛不可忍，過惡未盡故不死，在泥犁中甚長久，
translation: The five stores of intestines and stomach in the belly are all scorched, burned, and scorched. The poisonous pain they experience is unbearable. They do not die until their evil deeds have been done; they remain in the mud plow for a very long time.

source_sentence: 已後乃得出，便走求解脫。
translation: After that, he came out and ran away in search of liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名為飲，悉入其中，泥犁旁便問言：『欲求何等？』
translation: There's a mud plow named drinking, and they all enter it, and the other side of the mud plow asks, 'What do you want?'

source_sentence: 報言：『我但苦飢渴！』
translation: They replied, 'I'm only suffering from hunger and thirst!'

source_sentence: 泥犁旁即各各取其人身撲著燒熱地，以鉗拗開其口，以燒鐵丸著人口中，
translation: At the side of the mud plow, they each took their bodies and pushed them into a scorching hot place, opened their mouths with forceps, burned iron balls, and placed them among the people.

source_sentence: 脣舌咽皆燋，五臟腸胃盡燋，便下過去，毒痛不可忍，過惡未解故不死，
translation: Their lips, tongue, and throat all blistering, their five internal organs, intestines, stomach, and stomach are all burned away, and they pass away. The pain of the poison cannot be tolerated, so they won’t die until they have undergone excruciating torture.

source_sentence: 在其中甚長久，乃從飲泥犁中出，便走求解脫。
translation: After staying there for a long time, he emerged from the mud plow and ran away in search of liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名一銅釜，縱廣二萬里，盡入中。
translation: “There is a mud plow called the copper pot, twenty thousand li long and twenty thousand li in width, all entering into it.

source_sentence: 泥犁旁便共舉人身體手足著釜中煮，在底亦熟在上亦熟，湯沸踊躍起伏，
translation: Beside the mud plow, they all lifted their bodies, hands and feet, and put them into the pot to cook. At the bottom it was cooked, and at the top it was cooked as well. The water boiled and jumped up and down in unison.

source_sentence: 有在上露手足者覆亦熟，譬如煮豆，在底亦熟在上亦熟，覆亦熟露亦熟。
translation: If someone exposes their hands and feet above, they're covered and also cooked, like boiling beans that are cooked at the bottom and cooked above, which are covered and cooked and exposed as well.

source_sentence: 泥犁中人亦如是，在二萬里銅釜泥犁中，上下皆熟，頭面耳鼻手足皆見熟爛。
translation: So it is with the people in the mud plows, who are 20,000 miles away in a copper pot and mud plow, whose heads, faces, ears, nose, hands, and feet all see ripening and rotting.

source_sentence: 泥犁旁以矛刺內其中，毒痛不可忍，過惡未解故不死，用是故在其中甚久長，
translation: To the side of the mud plow he thrusts a spear into it, which inflicts unbearable pain and suffering. He does not die until his offenses have been resolved. Because of this functioning, he remains in this hell for a very long time.

source_sentence: 已後乃從一銅釜泥犁中出，便走欲求解脫。
translation: After that, he emerged from the mud plow of a copper cauldron and ran away in order to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名多銅釜，縱廣二萬里悉入中，泥犁旁便各各舉其身手足著釜中，
translation: There was a mud plow called “many copper pots” twenty thousand li in length and thirty thousand li in width, which all entered the furnace. Beside the mud plow they each put their bodies, hands, feet, and hands into it.

source_sentence: 湯沸踊躍，展轉在底在上，頭面手足皆見熟爛，泥犁旁便以矛[打-丁+鳥]罪人，
translation: The water boiled and jumped forth, rising up to the bottom. The sinners’ heads, faces, hands, and feet all looked as if they were cooked. Beside the mud plow was a spear that struck the sinners.

source_sentence: 持著餘釜中見煮亦如是，毒痛不可忍，過惡未解故不死，在其中甚長久，
translation: So it is when one holds and cooks in another cauldron. The pain of the poisonous poison cannot be tolerated, and because they are not yet liberated from their evil deeds they do not die. They remain in this cauldron for a very long time.

source_sentence: 已後乃從多銅釜泥犁中出，便走欲求解脫。
translation: After that, he emerged from the mud plow of many copper cauldrons and ran away in order to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名磨，縱廣二萬里悉入其中，泥犁旁便各各取人，著鐵磨上臥，
translation: “There’s a mud plow called grinding, twenty thousand li in length and width that all enters into it. At the side of each mud plow there are two kinds of people:

source_sentence: 以蓋覆，便捉磨使碎，血肉流下，骨留在磨，中火出燒，炙毒痛不可忍，
translation: They cover it with a canopy and crush it into bits of flesh and blood. The bones are left to be crushed, and the fire that burns them in the midst of it causes unbearable pain and suffering.

source_sentence: 過惡未解故不死，用是故在其中甚長久，已後乃從鐵磨泥犁中出，便走欲求解脫。
translation: Because their faults and evils haven't been untied, they won't die; it's because of this that they stay there for a long time. After that, they emerge from the iron-ground plow and run away to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名膿血，縱廣二萬里，人悉入其中，即自然有膿血火焰出，人以手足把歷欲出，
translation: “There is a mud plow called pus and blood, twenty thousand li in length and breadth. All the people who enter into it naturally produce pus and blood as flames of fire.

source_sentence: 頭面耳鼻身體手足皆燋，便自以手取膿血食之，脣舌咽皆燋，腹中腸胃五臟皆燋，
translation: Their heads, faces, ears, nose, bodies, hands, feet, and nails are all gross, so they take the pus and blood with their own hands and eat it. Their lips, tongue, and throat are all gross, and everything in their belly, intestines, stomach, and five internal organs are all gross.

source_sentence: 便下過去，毒痛不可忍，過惡未解故不死，在其中甚長久，已後乃從膿血泥犁中出，
translation: So they came down and passed away, suffering unbearably from the pain of the poison. Because their faults were not yet resolved they did not die. After remaining there for a very long time, they emerged from the plow drawn with pus, blood, and mud.

source_sentence: 便走欲求解脫。
translation: He then ran away in order to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名高峻，縱廣二萬里，人悉入其中，泥犁火焰出，泥犁旁即走人上下山，
translation: “There is a mud plow called Vaiśravaṇa, twenty thousand li in length and thirty thousand li in width. All the people walk up and down the mountain beside it.

source_sentence: 頭面耳鼻身體手足皆燋爛，毒痛不可忍，過惡未解故不死，在其中甚長久，
translation: Their heads, faces, ears, nose, bodies, hands, and feet are all scorched and burned away. The pain of the poison cannot be tolerated. Because their faults have not been resolved, they do not die. They remain in this hell for a long time.

source_sentence: 已後乃從高峻泥犁中出，便走欲求解脫。
translation: After that, he emerged from the high mud plow and ran away in order to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名斫板，縱廣二萬里，人悉入中，泥犁旁便各各取人，撲燒鐵地，
translation: “There is a mud plow called the hollow plank, twenty thousand li in length and thirty thousand li in width. All the people enter into it. At the side of each mud plow they pick up their own hands and throw them down on an iron ground.

source_sentence: 以鐵繩量度其身，以兩手持斧，斫削身及頭面手足鼻耳，毒痛不可忍，
translation: He measures his body with an iron rope, carries an axe in both hands, and cuts off his body, head, face, hands, feet, nose, and ears. The pain of the poison cannot be endured.

source_sentence: 過惡未解故不死，在其中甚長久，已後乃從斫板泥犁中出，便走欲求解脫。
translation: Because their faults and evils haven't been untied, they won't die; they stay there for a very long time. After that, they emerge from the mud plow of coarse boards and then run away to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名斛，縱廣二萬里，人悉入其中，泥犁旁即取炭火中人，使著斛中量，
translation: “There is a mud plow called ‘hu’ twenty thousand li in length and width. All the people enter into it. Beside the mud plow, they take the coal from the ground and burn it to make it weigh as much as one hu [to be transported].

source_sentence: 以手摩上，頭面身體手足鼻耳皆燋爛，泥犁旁走人火上，往還燒炙，毒痛不可忍，
translation: Their heads, bodies, hands, feet, noses, and ears are all burned away. Someone walking beside a mud plow is thrown back and forth into the fire and burned to death in unbearable pain.

source_sentence: 過惡未解故不死，在其中甚長久，已後乃從斛泥犁中出，便走欲求解脫。
translation: Because their faults and evils haven't been untied, they won't die; they stay there for a long time. After that, they emerge from the tub of clay plow and run away to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名劍樹葉，縱廣二萬里，人悉入其中，風生吹鐵劍樹葉墮，落截人手足頭面耳鼻身體，
translation: “There’s a mud plow called Sword-tree Leaf, twenty thousand li in length and thirty thousand li in width. When people enter it, the iron sword- tree leaves blown by wind fall off, cutting off their hands, feet, heads, faces, ears, nose, and body.

source_sentence: 毒痛不可忍，過惡未解故不死，在其中甚長久，已後乃從鐵劍樹泥犁中出，
translation: The poison and pain they experience cannot be tolerated. They are not allowed to die until their offenses have been expiated. After remaining in this hell for a very long time, they emerge from the iron sword-like tree or mud plow.

source_sentence: 便走欲求解脫。
translation: He then ran away in order to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名撓撈河，縱廣二萬里，河兩邊生剃頭刀草，人悉入其中，刀逆刺人，
translation: “There’s a mud plow called ‘dragging up the river.’ Twenty thousand li in length and breadth, shaving one’s hair with a sword and blade grows on both banks of the river. All the people enter it, but the sword pierces them directly.

source_sentence: 斷人手足頭面鼻耳身體，毒痛不可忍。
translation: Their hands, feet, heads, faces, noses, ears, and bodies are cut off, and the pain of poison cannot be tolerated.

source_sentence: 「爾時，人皆墮撓撈河，湯沸涌躍，下底有八寸蒺[卄\/梨]刺，刺人身血流灑，
translation: At that time, the people all fell down and drew water from the river. Boiling water bubbled high and jumped up and down in uncooked water. On the bottom of the stream was an eight-inch thick thorn, which pierced their bodies and dropped blood onto them.

source_sentence: 但有其骨，便沸涌躍轉上人，毒痛不可忍，風吹至岸邊草，刀逆向內，
translation: But if someone has a bone, they'll boil and jump up and down. The poisonous pain won't be tolerable, and the wind blows into the grass at the edge of the shore, with its sword pointing inward.

source_sentence: 截人頭面耳鼻身體手足，毒痛不可忍，過惡未解故不死，泥犁旁即問人言：『欲求何等。』
translation: He cuts off the head, face, ears, nose, body, hands, and feet of a person whose venomous pain can't be tolerated, and he doesn't die because his past evil hasn't been untied. Beside the mud plow, he asks someone, 'What do you want?'

source_sentence: 報言：『我但苦飢渴！』
translation: They replied, 'I'm only suffering from hunger and thirst!'

source_sentence: 泥犁旁便各各取人撲著燒熱地，以消銅灌人口中，脣舌咽喉皆燋，身體五臟腸胃皆燋，
translation: Beside the mud plow, they each took a man and pushed him into a scorching hot place. He poured molten copper into the living beings’ mouths to extinguish the heat. Their lips, tongues, throats, and throats were all scorched; their bodies, five internal organs, intestines, stomach, and stomach were all scorched.

source_sentence: 便下過去，毒痛不可忍，過惡未解故不死。
translation: He then went down and passed away, suffering unbearably from the poison and pain, and he didn't die because his faults hadn't been resolved.

source_sentence: 河兩邊有鐵樹，泥犁旁便取人舉著鐵樹下，樹生刺刺下垂，刺人身體，
translation: On both banks of the river there are iron trees. Next to the plows drawn by the mud, they pick up the dead bodies and place them under an iron tree. The thorns grow on top of the trees and hang down their branches, which pierce the bodies of those beings.

source_sentence: 血肉流墮，餘但有骨，風起吹人身體，平復如故；
translation: The blood and flesh flowed down but the rest had bones. When the wind rose and blew the body of the man was restored to its original form.

source_sentence: 有鳥名鐵烏喙，啄其頭噉其腦，在頭上住，啄取人瞳子，人欲下鐵刺向仰刺人，
translation: There's a bird named the iron crow beak that pecks at its head and pierces its brain, standing on top of it. It pecks to get people's pupils, and when they want to put down an iron thorn, it spits upward and strikes them.

source_sentence: 欲上向下刺人。
translation: They want to go upward, face downward, and stab people.

source_sentence: 爾時人走行欲求解脫，還墮撓撈河中，湯沸涌躍墮底，為蒺[卄\/梨]所刺如故，
translation: At that time the people, wanting to seek liberation, ran back and fell into the river. The water boiled and jumped up and down to the bottom but they were still pierced by the current as before.

source_sentence: 上堓浮風吹堓邊，刀逆截傷人頭面耳鼻身體手足，毒痛不可忍，過惡未解故不死，
translation: When the wind blows at the edge of the river, a sharp sword goes up and cuts their heads, faces, ears, nose, bodies, hands, and feet. The pain is unbearable; they do not die until they have overcome evil and are freed from it.

source_sentence: 樹泥犁旁問言：『欲求何等？』
translation: Beside the tree and mud plow, he asked, 'What do you want?'

source_sentence: 言：『我但苦飢渴！』
translation: They say, 'I'm only suffering from hunger and thirst!'

source_sentence: 便持消銅灌口中，脣舌咽喉腸胃皆，燋爛，便下過去。
translation: He then poured the cessation copper into his mouth, and his lips, tongue, throat, intestines, and stomach were all scorched and rotten, so he went down and passed away.

source_sentence: 上堓邊，泥犁旁復著堓邊樹上，欲下上刀逆刺人；
translation: On the side of the upper part of the carriage, next to the mud plow, he puts his sword on a tree at the edge of the carriage and intends to draw down another sword in order to pierce the man.

source_sentence: 有鳥名那尼喙，啄人頭噉其腦，在人頭上啄人瞳子，欲上下刺逆向刺人，
translation: There's a bird named Nāgârjuna beak that pecks at people's heads and pierces their brains. On top of someone's head, it pecks at their pupils, wanting to spit up and down and twirl back and forth against them.

source_sentence: 毒痛不可忍，過惡未盡故不死。
translation: The pain and suffering of the poison cannot be tolerated, and they won't die until their past evil has ended.

source_sentence: 復還墮撓撈河，在中毒痛如故，風復吹至堓邊，草刀逆刺剝人如故，泥犁旁復問人言：『欲求何等。』
translation: Again, he fell back into the river and was as painful as before. The wind blew up to the edge of the pond, drew a blade of grass against him, and stripped him away as before. Beside the mud plow, he asked the man again, 'What do you want?'

source_sentence: 報言：『但苦飢渴！』
translation: They replied, 'It's just suffering hunger and thirst!'

source_sentence: 以其消銅灌其口中如故，燒炙毒痛不可忍，在其中甚長久，已後乃從撓撈河得出，
translation: He poured the molten copper into his mouth as before and burned it, inflicting unbearable pain and suffering. After remaining there for a very long time, he came out of the Nimindhara and escaped from the river.

source_sentence: 便走欲求解脫。
translation: He then ran away in order to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名狼野干，縱廣二萬里，人悉入其中，狼野干自然在前住，身中出火焰，
translation: “There’s a mud plow called the wolf-grasping, twenty thousand li in length and thirty thousand li in width, where people enter. The wolf-grasping will naturally stand in front of them, and fire blazes forth from their bodies.

source_sentence: 所齧人身肉，應其口而食之，毒痛不可忍，飛鳥共來，啄噉人者，脫人眼者，
translation: They feed on the flesh and blood of those beings who eat it, eating it according to their mouths. The poison and pain they experience cannot be tolerated.

source_sentence: 毒痛不可忍，過惡未盡故不死，在其中甚長久，已後乃從狼野干泥犁得出，
translation: The pain of the poison cannot be tolerated. They do not die until all their evil deeds have been done, and after remaining in this hell for a very long time, they emerge from the wilderness of the wolf’s rebirth by drying up the mud plow.

source_sentence: 便走欲求解脫。
translation: He then ran away in order to seek liberation.

source_sentence: 「有泥犁名寒氷，縱廣二萬里，人悉入其中，風周匝四面起寒冷，吹人身肌膚皮肉筋骨入髓中，
translation: Again, there is a holy hell called Cold Ice, twenty thousand li in length and width, where the wind blows on all four sides to produce cold air. The skin, flesh, tendons, bones, and marrow of the human body are blown into it.

source_sentence: 用是故便於中死。」
translation: Because of this, they'll die in it.

source_sentence: 佛言：「何以故名為黑耳泥犁？
translation: The Buddha said, Why is it called the black-eared mud plow?

source_sentence: 若有人墮黑耳泥犁中者，黑風熱沙，雨其身上，即隨墮地，焦皮肌膚骨肉脂髓，
translation: If someone falls into a black-eared mud plow, the black wind blows and hot sand rain pours down on their bodies, and they fall to the ground along with it, scorching skin, soaking flesh, fat, and marrow.

source_sentence: 毒痛不可忍，過惡未盡故不死，用是故名為黑耳。
translation: The poisonous pain is unbearable, and they won't die because their past evil hasn't ended; this is why they're called black ears.

source_sentence: 復有餘因緣，復次，黑耳大泥犁，其有人墮中者，以燒鐵黑索縛其身，
translation: “Furthermore, there are other reasons. Again, if a black-eared plow is big like a great mud plow, and someone falls into it, they’ll be bound by an iron or black thread that burns their bodies.

source_sentence: 風便勒結之，斷其身皮肌膚，破骨出髓，毒痛不可忍，過惡未盡故不死，
translation: When the wind blows, they cut off the skin and flesh on their bodies, breaking open the bones and discharging the marrow. The pain of the poison cannot be endured. They are not allowed to die until all their evil has been done.
